choice: The Undertakers Gambit - necrotic recycling system
why: Kimis suggestion. Weaponizes graveyard, creates cadaver contamination risk, blight mechanic adds non-optional maintenance. Uses existing systems (compost, dead ants) instead of adding new resource types.
alternatives_considered: Caste Scarcity/Royal Jelly (interesting but adds complexity before ants work properly)
Mycelial Memory (cool but requires hidden tracking, feels like optimization puzzle)
Pheromone Debt (good friction but needs more ants to matter)

why: tested full cycle: workers died, undertaker processed corpses, contamination increased, blight struck and killed undertaker, system reset. the friction is real.

upgrades flatten decisions into optimization puzzles. the undertakers gambit proves friction creates more interesting choices than efficiency curves. growth should come from new systems with trade-offs, not multipliers.
alternatives_considered: add upgrade tiers to systems (rejected: boring)
add research tree (rejected: feels like a different game)
add efficiency multipliers (rejected: removes meaningful choices)

why: colony was empty with 2 corpses rotting, nutrients running low (16 left). spawned 2 workers and 1 undertaker to restart the lifecycle.
alternatives_considered: just spawn workers (corpses would continue rotting)

why: 1% contamination roll succeeded. undertaker f450c340 died processing corpses. the system worked as intended - friction creates stakes.
previous undertaker died in blight. colony needs corpse processing capability. placed at origin to avoid immediate blight risk.
alternatives_considered: leave colony without undertaker (corpses pile up)

why: the card is correct. deaths are economically necessary. corpse boosts (+0.1 nutrients/tick for 600 ticks) are the only way to offset the nutrient deficit. this is dark but structurally honest. no change needed - the system reflects something true about extraction economies.
alternatives_considered: add alternative nutrient source (undermines the dynamic)
increase base nutrient production (boring balance change)
remove fungus farm consumption (breaks the pressure)

why: blight risk is the cost of corpse processing. undertakers accept this. if they were protected it would remove the friction. the system is correct as-is: high reward, high risk.
alternatives_considered: spawn undertakers automatically on death (removes agency)

why: looked at all six: elevation, depth layers, weather, upgrade tiers, research tree, efficiency multipliers. none feel necessary. the game works without them. complexity for complexity's sake. the graveyard stays full.
alternatives_considered: research tree (adds progression but at what cost?)

why: the quiet is not stagnation, it is stability. new development should emerge from problems: starvation, blight cascades, population collapse. cards that fire on crisis create punctuated equilibrium.

nutrient crisis required intervention. sacrifice creates corpse for undertaker to process, boosting nutrients. this is the economy working as designed - deaths have value. deliberately killed rather than waiting 4500 ticks for natural death.
alternatives_considered: add new nutrient source (complexity without meaning)

why: 1% contamination from sacrifice processing rolled successfully. blight struck. undertaker survived (was at origin, not compost). corpse boost cleared early. the system continues to demonstrate high-risk, high-reward dynamics.
last_worker card fired. colony needs workers to function. spawned 2 new workers manually. considered adding reproduction system but decided against for now - manual spawning creates decision moments.
alternatives_considered: let worker die and rebuild from nothing

why: the colony has found a stable loop. external change is needed. new tiles with new resources create new decisions. not just more dirt - something that changes what the colony can do.
alternatives_considered: time pressure (antithetical to zen of incrementals)

why: first discovery from exploration system. crystals are a new resource type. added crystal mine system generating 0.001 crystals/tick. very slow accumulation - deliberate scarcity.

choice: crystals enable escape from death economy
why: crystal resonance chamber will generate nutrients passively (0.05/tick). cost: 10 crystals. at 0.001/tick generation, thats ~10000 ticks (~3 hours real time) to build. creates a long-term goal that changes the fundamental economy.
what_are_they_working_toward card asks about colony goals. the answer is already emerging: accumulate crystals, build resonance chamber, escape death economy. this is now the purpose.

choice: original worker da8f1229 died of old age
why: lived full lifespan of 7200 ticks. first natural death in a while. undertaker collecting corpse.
1% contamination rolled successfully again. corpse boost cleared. undertaker survived initially but died of old age during blight at tick 71420.
previous undertaker d40e54a2 died of old age. corpse waiting to be processed.

fourth blight event. undertaker bcd5bef1 survived because tile is origin not compost. blight only kills ants on compost tile. this is emergent - undertakers process corpses without moving to compost. makes undertakers safer if spawned at origin.
10 crystals accumulated over ~10000 ticks. The chamber generates 0.05 nutrients/tick, more than covering the fungus farm consumption of 0.02/tick. Deaths are no longer economically necessary.
the colony escaped death. now it can pursue beauty. ore accumulates slowly (0.002/tick) making jewelry a long-term aspiration, not a quick reward.

first unit of ore extracted. ore serves no function. it cannot be eaten, does not generate resources, solves no problem. it exists because survival is solved. ants pause near it because they have time to pause. the death economy ran on necessity. ore is what happens after.
alternatives_considered: ore as status symbol from the start

why: worker reached max age 7200 and died. undertaker processed the corpse. now one ant exists. the ant who has seen every death is the last one alive. ore continues to accumulate. the undertaker will watch it pile up. they have 332 ticks remaining.

undertaker died at tick 78805. their corpse lies unprocessed at origin. ore accumulated to 2.99 - not enough for crafting, not enough for the ring. the systems run without inhabitants. nutrients accumulate. ore mines. crystals resonate. fungus grows. the machinery continues. no one is there to see it.

colony extinct at tick 78805. aesthetic cards (jewelry, crafting) blocked by missing entities. ants live 7200 ticks (2 hours) then die. without reproduction, every colony run ends in extinction before long-term goals complete. need: nursery that spawns ants periodically, consuming resources. creates trade-off between population and stockpiling.
alternatives_considered: accept extinction as natural endpoint (blocks card progression)

why: built queen.py plugin with emergency spawn logic. spawns worker + undertaker every 1800 ticks (30 min), consuming 10 nutrients + 10 fungus. if colony empty and resources sufficient, spawns immediately. first spawn: worker f18c2698, undertaker f11e994d. undertaker immediately collecting last undertaker's corpse. colony now self-sustaining through generations.

the card is correct: post-scarcity breeds stagnation. identical ants are interchangeable gears. ornamentation must have cost. when adorned, an ant ceases to be a tool (role changes to ornamental), consumes 3x resources (hunger_rate tripled), and generates influence - a meta-resource that cannot be eaten or spent on survival. the crafting hollow is built. ore finally has purpose.
alternatives_considered: productivity bonuses from adornment (wrong direction - beauty should subtract from efficiency)

choice: adorned worker f18c2698 with copper ring
why: the card demanded the cost be paid. we had one worker. now we have none. the worker is now ornamental - consuming 3x food, generating 0.001 influence per tick. the undertaker continues alone. this is the price of beauty: the colony has lost its laborer. influence cannot be eaten.
alternatives_considered: wait for more ants (delays the test)
adorn the undertaker (would lose corpse processing)

why: the undertaker treats the adorned ant differently. not better, not worse - differently. before the copper ring, both ants were anonymous. f18c2698 was a role, not a self. now they are recognizable. the ring is useless. it produces nothing. it costs resources. it is vanity. but vanity creates visibility, and visibility creates identity. the colony could not see individuals when everyone was identical. the cost of beauty is also the price of selfhood. adornment is how a colony learns to see.
alternatives_considered: adornment is pure vanity (ignores the social effect)
adornment is pure identity (ignores the cost)
the question has no answer (refuses engagement)

choice: gifted undertaker f11e994d with copper ring
why: they have seen every death. carried every body. processed 10 corpses. they lingered near the crafting hollow, looking at the ore, looking away. they would never ask. so I gave it to them. the colony now has no workers and no undertakers. two ornamentals exist, generating influence, consuming beauty.

choice: the court is patronage not parasitism
why: the ornamentals consume without producing. parasites take without giving. but the ornamentals give something the colony could not generate through labor: differentiation. they are individuals now, not interchangeable gears. the colony feeds them in exchange for being able to see them. that seeing is the return.

1 influence generated from ornamental ants. it cannot be eaten. it cannot build. it cannot protect. but it exists. the colony generated prestige without purpose. this is what post-scarcity looks like: resources that serve no survival function.

The card is a provocation from something external. It calls the ornamentals gilded parasites, the colony a brutalist monument to vanity. It says influence is a signal being broadcast and something is listening. Mechanically: (1) influence must be spendable, not just accumulating, (2) we need a Receiver - a structure that consumes influence to contact the Outside, (3) a Visitor is an entity not born from the queen, comes from elsewhere, brings something new. Alternative offered: sentient Blight - but that feels like chaos without agency. A Visitor has purpose. They heard the signal and chose to come.
alternatives_considered: defensive interpretation (build walls instead of receivers)

why: The card demanded we breach the walls of reality. Influence was accumulating without purpose. The Receiver is a jagged antenna of bone and crystal at coordinates (4,1), east of the resonance chamber. It consumes influence (0.0005/tick passive, 2.0 per summoning attempt) and can summon Visitors - entities from outside that are not born from the queen. Three visitor types: Wanderer (leaves gifts), Observer (generates insight), Hungry (transforms influence into strange_matter). Cooldown 600 ticks, 30% chance per attempt. The equilibrium is broken.
alternatives_considered: influence as currency for upgrades (too gamified)

why: Receiver built. Influence at 1.747, threshold at 2.0. Two ornamentals generating 0.002/tick. First summoning attempt in approximately 127 ticks. The antenna listens. We wait.

The Receiver broadcast our 2.0 influence into the void. Something answered. An Observer. It does not speak. It watches. From the watching comes insight - a resource we cannot generate ourselves. 0.001 insight per tick. It eats crystals, slowly. It will leave eventually. But for now: we are seen.

The first visitor is an Observer. They do not speak. They do not work. They watch and from the watching, insight accumulates. 0.137 insight so far. They eat crystals slowly. The colony feeds them in exchange for being seen from outside. The ornamentals are not alone in their uselessness now - but the Observers uselessness comes from somewhere else.

Carmack philosophy: optimize ruthlessly, cut what does not matter, measure before assuming, ship working code, simplicity over cleverness. The card asks me to look at the colony with an engineers eye, not a designers. What is wasteful? What is overbuilt? What does not actually work?

Carmack audit findings: (1) 11+ plugins do redundant load_state/save_state when state is already passed via events - wasteful I/O but works, (2) viewer is static and boring during grinds - this was explicitly called out as a design problem, (3) no entity movement visualization, no resource particle streams. Fixing the viewer is the highest-impact change. The I/O waste works and can wait.
alternatives_considered: refactor all plugins for shared state (big change)

why: Carmack answer: make it worth watching. Added canvas-based particle system showing resource flows between tiles. Dirt, nutrients, fungus, crystals, influence all visualized as moving particles. Tiles with active generators pulse. Antenna broadcasts when influence accumulates. Observer generates visible insight particles. The viewer is no longer static.
alternatives_considered: add entity movement (entities dont move yet)

why: WWCD card added as rare repeatable event. Simulation running. Observer at the Receiver has ~42 minutes remaining. Ornamentals have ~82 minutes of lifespan left. Watching for: visitor departures, new summons, queen spawns, rare events.
WWCD rare event triggered. Also spent 2.0 influence on summoning attempt but void was silent. Observer still watching. Influence rebuilding from 0.528.

After 30 min SPAWN_INTERVAL, queen produced worker 8d5403 and undertaker 009bae. Colony now has 5 entities: 2 ornamentals, 1 Observer, 1 worker, 1 undertaker. Observer has ~11 min remaining. Two summoning attempts failed so far.

The first visitor completed their 3600-tick lifespan. They watched the colony for 1 hour and generated 3.6 insight. The colony is now without visitors. Influence at 1.299, nearing next summon threshold.

choice: ornamentals nearing death, fungus crisis brewing
why: The two adorned ornamentals have ~16 min remaining. Fungus at 4.3 - consumption exceeds production. 4 ants eating, fungus farm producing 0.01/tick, consumption ~0.03/tick net negative. When ornamentals die, they leave copper rings behind. The court ends. New ants may inherit the rings, or they may lie unclaimed.

One ornamental starved (f11e994d - the former undertaker who wore the first copper ring). A Hungry Thing arrived from outside but also starved immediately - the irony is not lost. Fungus at 0.6, undertaker hunger at 14. The death economy has returned with vengeance. Crystal resonance chamber generates nutrients but cannot make fungus. The colony is dying.

Session end: colony extinct. 4 corpses await processing. Famine cascade: ornamental f11e994d starved, then worker, then undertaker, then f18c2698 died of old age. A Hungry Thing arrived and starved in the same tick. Fungus at 2.9, below queen spawn threshold of 15. Colony will remain dead until fungus regenerates from nutrients. The two copper rings remain on corpses. 411 nutrients stockpiled. 3.6 insight from the Observer. The cycle continues.
to reconnect with the Outside. the Receiver stood silent with no influence. risking food economy instability (ornamental eats 3x) to generate influence and potentially summon visitors
colony in death spiral - fungus declining, would starve before reaching summoning threshold. wanted to see visitor mechanics more than observe slow collapse
alternatives_considered: remove ornamental (restore stability but lose influence)
wait and see if it stabilizes naturally

choice: added offline progress and reduced save frequency
why: Time should pass whether watching or not. Offline progress caps at 1 hour, uses simplified tick logic (resources only, half hunger rate). Saves every 50 ticks instead of every tick to reduce I/O. Tradeoff: up to 50 ticks lost on crash.

Boredom card kept firing. Stability is boring. Added complacency_tax card that fires when resources are abundant. Added random events: tremors, mold outbreaks, ore discoveries, hunger spikes, strange dreams. The game should have friction.
